Identifying Characteristics: Usually brown, brick red, or olive-colored with light-colored patterns and brown spots on their backs
All have warts and some have a light stripe down their back
Have special paratoid glands that produce a foul-smelling and toxic chemical to keep predators away
Size: Typically growing between 2" and 4.5" long
Biology: Males have a darker throat than females
Male calls/unique songs attract females to pools of water to begin mating in the Spring
Females lay long strands of thousands of eggs in the water attached to plants and fertilization occurs in water
Tadpoles hatch within a week and will steadily grow over a month when they emerge from the water as young toads
During the day they hide under leaves, logs and rocks to keep their skin moist and become predators at night
In the Fall and Winter seasons they will hibernate and burrow up to three feet underground
They can live up to 30 years.
Habitat: Anywhere moist - gardens, lawns, woods, ponds, etc.
Diet: Adult toads eat a lot: mainly insects, spiders, earthworms, snails, slugs, or just about anything that will fit into their mouth
